metadata.title: Simultaneously increasing the elevated-temperature tensile strength and plasticity of in situ nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composites

sections.text:

particles were fabricated by combustion synthesis (CS) and hot pressing process combined with hot extrusion. Results showed that the tensile strength, yield strength and fracture strain of the composites were simultaneously improved compared with powder metallurgy (PM) Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 493-573 K. For instance, in comparison with Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 573 K, the tensile strength and fracture strain of 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composite increased by 2.4% and 196.0%, while those of the composites reinforced with 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles increased by 26.6% and 73.7%. Meanwhile, the mechanism of simultaneous increase in tensile strength and plasticity of the present composites at high temperature was discussed.

Simultaneously increasing the elevated-temperature tensile strength
and plasticity of in situ nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composites
Abstract: Al-Cu-Mg matrix composites reinforced with 5-9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles were fabricated by combustion synthesis (CS) and hot pressing process combined with hot extrusion. Results showed that the tensile strength, yield strength and fracture strain of the composites were simultaneously improved compared with powder metallurgy (PM) Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 493-573 K. For instance, in comparison with Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 573 K, the tensile strength and fracture strain of 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composite increased by 2.4% and 196.0%, while those of the composites reinforced with 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles increased by 26.6% and 73.7%. Meanwhile, the mechanism of simultaneous increase in tensile strength and plasticity of the present composites at high temperature was discussed. Keyword: Al matrix composites (AMCs); Nano-sized TiCx; EBSD; High temperature tensile properties; Strengthening mechanisms.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
Nano-sized particles reinforced aluminum matrix composites (AMCs) exhibit a
high strength and good ductility, and meanwhile offer superior wear, creep and fatigue performance [1-13]. These prominent properties enable them to be potential materials for high temperature applications in automobile and aerospace industries. However, the acquirement of well dispersed nano-sized particles and good particle-matrix
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
interface in the matrix are essential for the practical application of such materials [5,7].
Good distribution of nano-sized particles in the Al matrix is a challenge on
account of its extremely huge surface area and high surface energy [8]. Many methods have been developed to incorporate nano-sized particles into Al matrix, which could be divided into ex-situ [4,9-11] and in-situ fabrication methods [3,7]. Commonly the reinforced particles introduced by ex-situ method are susceptible to contamination and tend to agglomerate due to the poor wettability between the matrix and reinforcement, resulting in the degradation of the particle-matrix interface as well as the mechanical properties at both room and elevated temperature [5]. On the contrary, the particles generated by in situ methods, including combustion synthesis, molten salt, etc., are usually fine and have cleaner particle-matrix interface [12,13]. Han et al.[7] introduced 4 wt% nano-sized TiB2 into Al-Si alloy through the exothermic reaction of hybrid K2TiF6 and KBF4 in the molten matrix alloy. They reported that the composite possessed higher modulus than that of the Al-Si alloy at 20 C-350 C, but no apparent increase in the tensile properties. Moreover, the regions containing clustered TiB2 particles were damaged first in the composite. Recently, Zhou et al. [3] prepared nano-sized TiC-Al master alloy via combustion synthesis method and then dispersed it into the molten Al-Cu alloy to obtain nano-sized TiCp/Al-Cu composites. They found that the composites exhibited high tensile strength and excellent elongation, which increased by 11.08% and 187.9%, respectively compared with those of the Al-Cu alloy. However, further research on their high temperature tensile properties
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
was not carried out.
In previous work [14], a combined method of CS and hot pressing followed by
hot extrusion was used to prepare nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites. Compared with PM 2009Al alloy, the composites reinforced with various volume fractions of nano-sized TiCx particles exhibit high strength but their fracture strain markedly decreased at room temperature. Nevertheless, high temperature tensile properties of the present composites are unknown, making a further study necessary. In this paper, the high temperature mechanical properties of 5-9 vol.% nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites were investigated at 493-573 K, and the strengthening mechanisms were discussed in detail as well.

sections.heading: 2. Experiment
sections.text:
The used raw materials were CNTs (10 nm-20 nm in diameter and 20µm-100
µm in length), Ti powders (~48 µm) and 2009Al alloy powders (~75 µm). 2009Al alloy contained 3.7 wt%Cu, 1.3 wt%Mg, 0.25 wt%Si, 0.05 wt%Fe and Bal. Al. Firstly, CNTs were milled alone for 2 h in a cylindrical stainless steel drum. Then the ground CNTs and Ti powders (molar ratio of 1:1) were mixed sufficiently with different volume fractions of 2009Al alloy powders by ball milling for 48 h. The same process was also used for 2009Al alloy powders. The blended powders and ball-milled 2009Al alloy powders were compressed into a cylinder (Φ45 mm×35 mm). The cylindrical compacts were then put into a self-made vacuum furnace and heated in a vacuum atmosphere. The combustion synthesis reaction happened when the temperature measured by the W5-Re26 thermocouple suddenly rose rapidly, and then
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
the reactants were quickly pressed while they were still hot and soft. Besides, the comparative sample for 2009Al alloy was manufactured by powder metallurgy (PM) in the same furnace. Hot extrusion process of 2009Al alloy and composites was conducted under an extrusion ratio of 19:1 at 773 K. The extruded samples were then T4-treated (solution treated at 783 K for 60 min, water quenching and then aged at room temperature for 96 h).
The samples were detected by transmission electron microscopy (TEM, JEM
2100F, Japan) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Tescan vega3 XM, Czech Republic) equipped with an Oxford NordlysMax EBSD detector. The samples prepared for EBSD characterization were first mechanical polishing up to 2000 mesh SiC (6.5 micron) abrasive paper, then fine polishing to mirror, and finally electro-polished with a hybrid solution of 20% HClO4-80% ethanol at 273 K. The step size (for EBSD maps) for 2009Al alloy and composites was 2 µm and 1µm, respectively. Maps were analyzed using the Oxford HKL Channel5 software package. Tensile tests were performed at a strain rate of 3×10 -4 s -1 on an INSTRON-5689 material testing machine at 493 K, 533 K and 573 K.

sections.heading: 3.1 High temperature tensile properties
sections.text:
Fig. 1 shows the engineering stress versus strain curves for PM 2009Al alloy and 5-9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites at 493 K, 533 K, and 573 K, respectively. The tensile test results are summarized in Table 1. The mechanical
AC
C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
strengths for 2009Al alloy and nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites show a sound dependence on temperature and nano-sized TiCx content. The fracture strain of these composites increases with the increase in temperature and decreasing content of the nano-sized TiCx. Moreover, the yield and tensile strength of the composites increase with increasing volume fraction of nano-sized TiCx. At 493K, 533K and 573K, the samples for 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composite possess the highest fracture strain, which are 28.4%, 74.5% and 196.0% higher than those of 2009Al alloy. Meanwhile, their tensile strengths increase 24.3%, 6.1% and 2.4%, respectively. In comparison with 2009Al alloy, the tensile strengths of the samples for 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites increase 38.6%, 18.4% and 26.6%, while the fracture strains increase 5.2%, 31.8% and 73.7%, respectively. The simultaneously improved mechanical strength and fracture strain should be mainly attributed to nano-sized TiCx particles and changes of the microstructure induced by incorporating nano-sized TiCx particles, which will be then discussed.
Table 1 The tensile test data of 2009Al and the composites at various temperatures.

sections.heading: 3.2 EBSD characterization
sections.text:
Fig. 2 shows the grain boundary (GB) maps overlaid with recrystallized microstructure of 2009Al alloy and composites reinforced with 5-9 vol. % TiCx particles. Meanwhile, the distributions of misorientation angles of those present
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
samples are shown in Fig. 3. In Fig. 2(a-d), low angle grain boundaries (LAGBs, 2-15°) and high angle grain boundaries (HAGBs, ≥15°) are visible through green and black lines, respectively. These maps exhibit fully recrystallized grains in blue, deformed regions in red and substructured grains (recovered with sub-grains) in yellow. The grain is classified as deformed when the average misorientation exceeds that of the user-defined value to define a sub-grain (2° in this study). If the grain consists of sub-grains whose average misorientation is under this value, yet the misorientation from sub-grain to sub-grain is between 2 and 15°, the grain is classified as substructured. All of the remaining grains are classified as recrystallized. It can be seen from Fig. 2(a) that the as-extruded 2009Al alloy possesses high recrystallization fraction of ~96% and its microstructure shows equiaxed grain shape with average grain size of 18.8 µm. Moreover, the EBSD map also reveals that the microstructure of 2009Al alloy consists of a very high fraction of HAGBs (fHAGB). The fractions of LAGBs (fLAGB), HAGBs (fHAGB) and the average misorientation angle of as-extruded 2009Al alloy are determined to 0.09, 0.91, and 32.1°, respectively (Fig.3 (a)).
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN
U
SC R
IP T
Fig. 2 GB maps overlaid with recrystallized microstructure of (a) 2009Al alloy and (b-d) nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites with 5-9 vol. % TiCx particles.
Fig. 3 Misorientation distribution in the grain structure of (a) extruded PM 2009Al and the composites with (b) 5 vol. %, (c) 7 vol. % and (d) 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx.
When the nano-sized TiCx particles were incorporated into 2009Al alloy, the
microstructure was drastically affected. Bimodal microstructures of small equiaxed grains and large grains containing a substructure can be observed in Fig. 2(c-d). With
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
nano-sized TiCx content increasing from 5 vol. % to 9 vol. %, the sizes of recrystallized grains distinctly decrease, meanwhile accompanying with the increase in deformation structure and substructured grains (red and yellow regions). Recrystallization fractions of 5-9 vol. % TiCx/2009Al composites are approximately determined to 81%, 69% and 44%, respectively. In addition, with the increase in nano-sized TiCx content, a marked decrease in HAGBs and a corresponding increase in LAGBs are observed in Fig. 2(b-d). As shown in Fig. 3(b-d), the fLAGB of samples for composites contained 5 vol. %, 7 vol. %and 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles are 56%, 79% and 95%, respectively. The average misorientation angles of these composites are 18.8°, 14.9° and 7.9°, respectively. It is well confirmed that nano-sized particles can affect the recrystallization microstructure of polycrystalline materials through Zener pinning [15-17]. In alloys that the ratio for volume fraction of particle to its diameter (Fv/d) is larger than 0.1 µm -1 , recrystallization is usually retarded [17]. Therefore, nano-sized TiCx particles can retard the motion of LAGBs and HAGBs in this study, and thus leading to retard of the recrystallization nucleation and subsequent growth. The Zener pinning effect of the grain boundaries increases with increasing nano-sized TiCx particles content, and thus leads to the decrease in the fraction of recrystallized structure.

sections.heading: 3.3 TEM Microstructure
sections.text:
In our present work, θ´ (Al2Cu) and S′ (Al2CuMg) precipitates are detected. Fig.
4 presents TEM micrographs of θ′ and S′ precipitates in 2009Al alloy and 9 vol.% nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites at 493–573 K after tensile test. The plate-shaped
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
θ′ precipitates and lath-shape S′ precipitates are observed along the <001> direction of the α-Al matrix. At 493 K, θ´ precipitates in the sample for 9 vol.% nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites have larger density and finer size (~150 nm) compared with those of the sample for 2009Al alloy (~300 nm), as shown in Figs. 4 (a) and 4(b). Meanwhile, an inhomogeneous distribution of S′ precipitates can also be seen in both 2009Al alloy and composites, and its sizes seem to be smaller in 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites than that in 2009Al alloy. At 533 K, both θ´ and S′ precipitates distinctly coarsen (Figs. 4(c) and 4(d)). It can be observed in Figs. 4(e) and 4(f) that θ´ and S′ precipitates coarsening become more apparent when increasing the temperature to 573 K. The mean length of θ´ precipitates in 2009Al alloy and composites are about 450 nm and 300 nm, respectively. It was reported that increasing content of the precipitates and reducing their average size will increase the tensile strength and fracture strain [18,19]. Nano-sized TiCx particles could retard recrystallization and hinder the growth of the recrystallized grains, and meanwhile the diffusion distance of Cu and Mg atoms also becomes shorter in α-Al grains during the solution process [20]. Therefore, the nucleation sites for the precipitates increase, and then the larger density as well as smaller size of θ´ and S′ precipitates formed in the composites during aging process. A large number of smaller-sized θ´ and S′ precipitated in composites can restrict and impede the dislocation movement, which is favorable for simultaneous improvement in strength and fracture strain.
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Fig. 4 TEM micrographs of θ′ and S′ precipitates in samples for 2009Al alloy and composites contained 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx at various condition after tensile test: the (a) 2009Al alloy and (b) 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites at 493K, the (c) 2009Al alloy and (d) 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites at 533K as well as the (e) 2009Al alloy and (f) 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites at 573K; insert: corresponding SAD pattern.
The above analyses imply that the simultaneously improved high temperature
tensile strength and fracture strain of composites have to be considered: (i) nano-sized TiCx strengthening, (ii) partially recrystallized microstructure induced by nano-sized TiCx and (iii) θ′ and S′ precipitation strengthening. Firstly, from the viewpoint of
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
Orowan dislocation bypassing mechanism, at high temperature, nano-sized TiCx particles inside the grain can pin down and accumulate dislocations within the grains. This dislocation accumulation inside the grains can give rise to the improvement of work hardening and fracture strain markedly, which have been proved by Liu et al.[21]. Secondly, nano-sized TiCx particles can pin the sub-boundaries, stabilize the sub-structure and subsequently retard recrystallization as well as the growth of the recrystallized grains. Partially recrystallized materials can increase the tensile strength and simultaneously improve the fracture strain in some extent [22]. That is because the formation of partially recrystallized microstructure consists of small equiaxed grains and large recrystallized grains. Large grains mainly store dislocations to improve fracture strain, while small equiaxed grains increase the strength. In addition, with increasing nano-sized TiCx content, the size of recrystallized grains decreases while the number of small equiaxed grain increases, as shown in Fig. 2. Therefore, the composite exhibits the highest fracture strain when volume fraction of nano-sized TiCx is 5%, while 9 vol.% nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composite possesses the highest strength with sacrificing a part of fracture strain. Thirdly, precipitation strengthening plays a significant role in improving tensile properties for aged 2009Al alloys, and the precipitates' size and number are of great significance. Compared with 2009Al alloy, the numbers of θ´ and S′ precipitates in composites increase and their sizes become smaller. But with increasing temperature, the size of θ′ and S′ precipitates will grow up and their numbers decrease in both 2009Al alloy and its composites. During high temperature deformation, the precipitate strengthening can only be workable when the
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
precipitate phase is good in high temperature stability and does not dissolve and coarsen. Thus effect of θ´ and S′ precipitates on elevated temperature mechanical behavior of nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites will weaken to some extent. The simultaneously improved tensile strength and fracture strain of nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composites is mainly attributed to the interactions between nano-sized TiCx strengthening, partially recrystallization as well as the θ′ and S′ precipitation strengthening.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
Microstructure and elevated temperature tensile properties of nano-sized
TiCx/2009Al composites prepared by combustion synthesis method assisted with hot pressing followed by hot extrusion were studied. Compared with PM 2009Al alloy at 493 K, 533 K and 573 K, the tensile strength of 2009Al matrix composites reinforced with 5 vol.%, 7 vol.% and 9 vol.% nano-sized TiCx particles increased and meanwhile accompanying with a markedly increase in fracture strain. The fracture strains of 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/2009Al composite increased by 28.4%, 74.5%, 196%, while the tensile strengths for composites containing 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles were 38.6%, 18.4%, 26.6% higher than those of 2009Al alloy at temperature of 493 K, 533 K, 573 K, respectively. Nano-sized TiCx particles could retard recrystallization and the growth of the recrystallized grains. Nano-sized TiCx particles and refined recrystallized grains increased the elevated temperature tensile strength, and dislocations accumulation inside the large recrystallized grains improved the fracture
AC C
EP TE
D M
AN U
SC R
IP T
strain of composites at high temperature. Our findings will provide a practical method to simultaneously improve high temperature tensile strength and plasticity of Al-Cu-Mg alloy-based composites.

metadata.abstractText: Al-Cu-Mg matrix composites reinforced with 5-9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles were fabricated by combustion synthesis (CS) and hot pressing process combined with hot extrusion. Results showed that the tensile strength, yield strength and fracture strain of the composites were simultaneously improved compared with powder metallurgy (PM) Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 493-573 K. For instance, in comparison with Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 573 K, the tensile strength and fracture strain of 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composite increased by 2.4% and 196.0%, while those of the composites reinforced with 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles increased by 26.6% and 73.7%. Meanwhile, the mechanism of simultaneous increase in tensile strength and plasticity of the present composites at high temperature was discussed. * Corresponding author. Tel./fax:+86 431 85094699. E-mail address: qiufeng@jlu.edu.cn (Feng Qiu), jqc@jlu.edu.cn (Qichuan Jiang). AC C EP TE D M AN U SC R IP T ACCEPTED MANUSCRIPT 2 Simultaneously increasing the elevated-temperature tensile strength and plasticity of in situ nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composites Abstract: Al-Cu-Mg matrix composites reinforced with 5-9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles were fabricated by combustion synthesis (CS) and hot pressing process Al-Cu-Mg matrix composites reinforced with 5-9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles were fabricated by combustion synthesis (CS) and hot pressing process combined with hot extrusion. Results showed that the tensile strength, yield strength and fracture strain of the composites were simultaneously improved compared with powder metallurgy (PM) Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 493-573 K. For instance, in comparison with Al-Cu-Mg alloy at 573 K, the tensile strength and fracture strain of 5 vol. % nano-sized TiCx/Al-Cu-Mg composite increased by 2.4% and 196.0%, while those of the composites reinforced with 9 vol. % nano-sized TiCx particles increased by 26.6% and 73.7%. Meanwhile, the mechanism of simultaneous increase in tensile strength and plasticity of the present composites at high temperature was discussed. Keyword: Al matrix composites (AMCs); Nano-sized TiCx; EBSD; High temperature tensile properties; Strengthening mechanisms.
